ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: About six. I spent a lot of time doing the reading and writing the reading responses. I also wrote the final paper over a few weeks which resulted in a lot of hours.
2-4 hours
6hrs
about 4-8
5-10 hours per week
Between 4 and 6.
2 hours

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: I learned new information is this course, but it was somewhat of a disappointment. The student presentations/exercises were not always well done and kind of disorganized. Considering half of the learning is through this method, I feel like I didn't get a lot out of it. I think there would be a lot of value to running this course like a real seminar where there is active discussion facilitated by the instructor.

I found the course very interesting and rewarding. The group led discussions were my least favorite aspect because I didn't find them very helpful for learning the material. I enjoyed Dr. Khoshnood's lectures, the two days we had visitors and the readings chosen for the course. I have also really liked writing the final paper.
the course was amazing. should be a req. course for EMD
Really good, especially the lectures with that had speakers come in!

Dynamic as a discussion-based course was good. Lectures were interesting and informative, professor certainly has a wealth of experience related to the subject-matter and was incredibly friendly and approachable. Discussions led by student groups varied in terms of value to the class; some groups tried to assign way too much work to accomplish during a short class time, which made the group activities feel rushed and stressful. Also, it would have been helpful to have a detailed syllabus at the beginning of the semester with readings lists and class assignments spelled out more than one or two weeks before the deadline. Finally, a mandatory meeting with the professor/TA to discuss the final paper a few weeks before it was due would have been helpful as it would have pushed me to plan for the final paper further in advance than I did.
Excellent course.Excellent professor.
The course overall was a very good look at the reality of HIV/AIDS both globally and in New Haven. Readings were very helpful and course instructor made the class very interactive.

Excellent. I felt like the course really came together in a coherent, meaningful way. This was definitely my favorite course of the semester.The guest lectures were great but the general lectures were also really informative and interactive. I think this course had a pretty great structure.I wasn't fond of my student-led discussion but I'm sure that was my fault.

Strengths would be the speakers such as the HIV positive individuals and those from CIRA and APNH. Those classes had the greatest impact. Kaveh is an amazing teacher and very knowledgeable. Weakness of the course was final paper being worth 40% of grade, and student presentations. I didn't feel I learned as much from them as from Kaveh's lectures and in class discussions. Maybe fewer presentations with larger groups.
Course material was interesting, relevant and logically sequenced.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  I think Kaveh is a great person who is genuinely interested in students, but again, I was disappointed. He seemed kind of bored and unenthusiastic about teaching the class. I thought the class itself would be more dynamic. It seems like most of the work is pawned off to the TA.

Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Dr. Khoshnood is a very knowledgeable instructor and a great lecturer. He works well with the student groups in preparing for discussion and is always attentive and responsive.
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Kaveh is an amazing prof, who respects students
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Good, thoughtful lectures and organization of the class.

Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Extremely friendly and approachable, has a great deal of knowledge regarding the subject. While he seemed prepared for all class lectures, it would have been helpful to have a better sense of the trajectory of the class in terms of written assignments. It was hard to plan when to complete class work because we did not have the assignments spelled out for us very far in advance. Also, it would help to have a required meeting with him and the TA mid-way through the course or even following Thanksgiving break to discuss our final project.
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Cool and nice.
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Kaveh is a fantastic instructor!

Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Dr. Khoshnood is a very good professor; really connects with students and focuses not only on understanding the political and public health impact of HIV/AIDS research but also the personal impact for individuals and families.
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Kaveh is really responsive and forced us to think critically. I really appreciated that, I don't think many other courses I've taken at YSPH did that.
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Kaveh is an amazing professor with a breadth and depth of knowledge.
Instructor: Kaveh Khoshnood  Kaveh was a very engaging instructor and also helped students to get the most out of the course by using student-lead discussions.

narratives.question_text: If this course included instruction by a teaching assistant (TA), please evaluate the TA here. What are the strengths and weaknesses and how might their teaching be improved? (Specify name of the TA).
comments: Rebecca was a good TA. She returned papers in a very timely manner and made the effort to comment on them, etc.

Rebecca was great and a very fair grader. It would have been nice if she lectured about her experiences working with an HIV/AIDS NGO in New York. She always responded to emails and helped during student-led discussions.
Rebecca was an ok TA, but could have been a little nicer
Good and very helpful.

Rebecca Erenrich was friendly, helpful, and provided great feedback in terms of written assignments. She responded very quickly to emails and provided constructive comments to any and all questions that I had.
Rebecca was a very good TA; always there to answer questions and was fully engaged in the course.
I think Rebecca was a fine TA.
Rebecca seemed somewhat scattered in some of her postings and didn't seem to contribute much to class discussions. She was responsive to emails.
RebeccaRebecca was very quick to respond to questions and gave meaningful feedback on writing assignments.

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: I'm not sure that I would recommend it if someone was deciding between two classes of equal interest. If you don't have a basic foundation on HIV and AIDS, I think it is worthwhile and actually a must for someone in a public health program--however, there may be better class options on the topic. Otherwise, the structure is not really that conducive to learning and it is disheartening to see what I considered a good professor who seems to actually be interested in students seem so uninterested in their own class.

I would say that it gives a good foundation about the history and current status of HIV globally. Many of the themes are also important to other health problems and issues. It is not too demanding but involves a lot of reading, writing and discussion. I would recommend it to anyone who has an interest in HIV/AIDS or global health.
imperative for EMD.
Really good course for anyone looking to learn more about different aspects of the HIV epidemic.

Great overview of HIV/AIDS and its continued relevance to public health. I would strongly recommend the course to anyone looking for a discussion -based class, with multiple opportunities to express ideas through written assignments.
Highly recommend. I really appreciate the classes with invited guests.
I would recommend this course to a fellow student; was a great addition and I definitely learned a lot about the context of global HIV/AIDS.
I'd recommend it.

This course is really great and I would recommend it to other students who are interested in HIV regardless of their level of experience with the epidemic. There is a lot to learn whatever level the student is at at the start of the course.
Yes, the course was very interesting and the instructor demonstrated his expertise on the subject material while also making the course very student-directed.
